channel.title: My Old Computer
channel.description:
I have a desktop that I rarely use because it is filled with viruses and is very slow. I want to basically wipe out everything and start fresh on it but honestly I have no idea how to do that and google hasn't been very helpful.
So, How can I completely erase my computer and start fresh?

item.title: My Old Computer
item.dc:creator: @lemme_winks lemme_winks_
item.description:
@lemme_winks wrote:

wasn’t there a thread similar to this…? oh wait, there was:

item.title: My Old Computer
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:3, topic:428463”][quote author=chillwitm888 link=topic=531157.msg3880046#msg3880046 date=1325973529]
and your i.p. address depends upon your Internet provider not your computer.
[/quote]

He never said anything about his IP address…

Backup any files you want to keep onto something like a flash drive or .zip them and upload it online.
Install Ubuntu onto a blank CD/DVD disk, run it on startup. Install Ubuntu over Windows and your Windows operating system will be completely gone. I recommend Ubuntu 10.04 instead of 11.10 because if you have a slower computer, it would be better to have the older version. I have both versions and installed them both, the older version works better than the newer version. I’m assuming the newer version requires more RAM or something.

Or yeah, just format your hard drive.

[/quote]
you can’t do that on the live OS

Read full topic

Install Ubuntu onto a blank CD/DVD disk, run it on startup. Install Ubuntu over Windows and your Windows operating system will be completely gone. I recommend Ubuntu 10.04 instead of 11.10 because if you have a slower computer, it would be better to have the older version. Or yeah, just format your hard drive.

[imsg]http://desmond.imageshack.us/Himg15/scaled.php?server=15&filename=formatom.png&res=medium[/img]

he also never said anything about switching operating systems
[/quote]

I’m recommending the operating system. Don’t be an ass, your IP thing was completely irrelevant.[/quote]
Kay, Just saying, I was just saying… Luv you friddo <3

item.title: My Old Computer
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Yes, I recommend install Linux, but if you choose to stick with Windows, just acquire a virtual copy. (Heh Heh) Burn it onto a CD, boot from the CD and it will give you a pretty user friendly menu, just select the option to install Windows, and from there you can format your partition and have a fresh install.

Read full topic

item.title: My Old Computer
item.dc:creator: @Repu Repu
item.description:
@Repu wrote:

You wont be able to format your drive fully if it’s in use, I’d recommend using your BIOS to handle such a task; you might have to ‘flash’ (upgrade) your BIOS if the computer is really old.
Then you can just install a fresh copy of Linux or Windows and use good anti-virus software to keep your machine running efficiently.

Read full topic

item.title: My Old Computer
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

You can format your hard drive. That will remove all data; but, otherwise your hardware will remain the same, and your i.p. address depends upon your Internet provider not your computer.

and secondly
If you have your Recovery CD/DVDs you must drop the partition and let setup from the CD/DVDs repartition and format. If your system does not come with Recovery CD/DVDs then make some, or if your system has been installed OEM then you can just use your OS CD and perform all of this. It might not have the file for dropping the partition, if that is the case then you’d need to find a DOS 5 (I think that is the lowest version that can be used? it’s been awhile) or better to perform these actions. The IP is from your Internet provider, you would have to change ISP to accomplish that. If you have a (wireless) router you can set the IP range to be different then the default.

Read full topic
